summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The government requests permission to redact names and identifying information of third parties from defense filings to protect their privacy, citing the Lugosch test. The defense and the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP take no position on the request.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced in the letter (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell).

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, to whom the government's letter is addressed.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who respectfully submits the letter.

events.title: Court Order on Redaction Requests
events.description: The Court issued an order directing the Government to submit any requests for redaction of information contained in filings regarding the defense's proposed Rule 17(c) subpoena.

events.title: Joint Letter on Redactions
events.description: A joint letter was submitted addressing redactions to documents related to the defense's proposed Rule 17(c) subpoena and objections from Boies Schiller Flexner LLP.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office is seeking court permission to redact names and identifying information of third parties from defense filings in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.
The requested redactions are to protect the privacy interests of third parties referenced in documents related to a defense Rule 17(c) subpoena.
The government argues the redactions are narrowly tailored and consistent with the legal test from Lugosch v. Pyramid Co. of Onondaga.
Both defense counsel and counsel from the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP take no position on the government's redaction requests.
The document is part of the procedural litigation surrounding evidence and privacy in the Maxwell prosecution.
